verses.text: For God alone my soul waits in silence; from him comes my salvation.
verses.comment: The psalmist expresses a soul quieted in patient expectation. The translation keeps the word 'alone,' which emphasizes the exclusivity of trusting in God—a theme found throughout the Psalms. In the Catholic spiritual tradition, such silence before God is deeply connected to interior contemplation and prayer (see Matt. 6:6).

verses.text: He alone is my rock and my salvation, my fortress; I will never be greatly shaken.
verses.comment: God as ‘rock,’ ‘salvation,’ and ‘fortress’ is traditional language for protection and stability. For Christian readers, this prefigures Christ as the cornerstone (see 1 Pet. 2:6).

verses.text: How long will you attack a man, all of you, to crush him, like a leaning wall, a tottering fence?
verses.comment: The psalmist’s enemies plot his downfall. The image highlights human frailty, and, spiritually, calls to humility and reliance on divine strength rather than self-assurance—a concept echoed by St. Paul (2 Cor. 12:10).

verses.text: They only plan to cast him down from his high position; they delight in lies. With their mouths they bless, but in their hearts they curse.
verses.comment: Duplicity is criticized here; blessing with the mouth but cursing inwardly reflects a divided heart. The literal sense applies to David’s enemies, the spiritual sense warns Christians against hypocrisy—a concern Jesus addressed (Matt. 23:28).

verses.text: For God alone, O my soul, wait in silence, for my hope comes from him.
verses.comment: Repetition in the psalm emphasizes the necessity for patience and trust in God. Catholic tradition values repeated prayer and silence as forms of hope-filled surrender in contemplative prayer.

verses.text: He alone is my rock and my salvation, my stronghold; I will not be shaken.
verses.comment: Echoes verse 2 almost exactly, intensifying the psalmist’s confidence. The doctrine of God as an unshakable ‘stronghold’ prefigures the security found in Christ, and by extension, the Church as a spiritual fortress (Matt. 16:18).

verses.text: On God rests my salvation and my glory; the rock of my strength, my refuge is in God.
verses.comment: Salvation and glory are recognized as God’s gifts. In Catholic theology, salvation is both a divine initiative and a shared glory (cf. Rom. 8:17)—pointing to our union with Christ and the saints.

verses.text: Trust in him at all times, O people; pour out your hearts before him. God is our refuge.
verses.comment: The exhortation is communal—‘O people’—encouraging all to open their hearts to God. Catholic liturgy often invites the faithful to ‘lift up your hearts,’ a Foreshadowing of corporate worship and sacramental life.

verses.text: Surely the lowly are a breath; the high-born are but a lie. If weighed together on the scales, they are lighter than a breath.
verses.comment: Human status is fleeting. The imagery anticipates Christian teaching on humility and the vanity of worldly distinctions (Jas. 1:10).

verses.text: Do not trust in extortion, nor set vain hope on stolen goods; if riches increase, do not set your heart on them.
verses.comment: The teaching warns against the idolatry of wealth—echoing Christ’s later instruction to store up spiritual treasure (Matt. 6:20). Detachment from riches is a central theme in Catholic monasticism and spiritual life.

verses.text: God has spoken once; twice have I heard this: that power belongs to God,
verses.comment: The repetition (‘once…twice’) intensifies certainty. Power belongs to God alone—a truth fulfilled in the risen Christ who claims ‘all authority’ (Matt. 28:18).

verses.text: and to you, Lord, belongs steadfast love; for you repay everyone according to his deeds.
verses.comment: God’s covenant love (‘steadfast love’) and justice are the conclusion of the psalm. The truth that God repays according to one’s deeds resonates with Christ’s teachings (Matt. 16:27) and underlines the necessity of both faith and works—a fundamental doctrine in Catholic soteriology.
